question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What league did John Hassan play in before 2000?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

**Breaking News: Boston University Alumnus John Hassan's NCAA Division I Legacy**

In a remarkable display of athletic prowess, John Hassan, a former college basketball player, made a name for himself in the prestigious NCAA Division I men's basketball league during his time at Boston University from 1969 to 1971. According to records obtained from Boston University's athletic department, Hassan was an integral part of the university's basketball team, competing against top-tier opponents in the NCAA Division I league. This elite league is comprised of the best college basketball programs in the United States, featuring powerhouses like Duke, Kentucky, and North Carolina. "John Hassan was an exceptional player who brought a high level of energy and dedication to our team," said Bob McKenney, Hassan's former coach at Boston University. "He was a key contributor to our success during those years, and we're proud to have had him represent our university in the NCAA Division I league." Data from the NCAA reveals that during Hassan's playing career, Boston University's basketball team competed in the NCAA Division I league, facing off against other top programs in the country. In fact, according to NCAA records, Boston University's team played in the NCAA Division I East Regional tournament in 1970, further solidifying Hassan's connection to the league. "John Hassan's participation in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league is a testament to his hard work and commitment to excellence," said Dr. Michael Lynch, Boston University's athletic director. "We're proud to count him among our alumni and celebrate his achievements on and off the court." In conclusion, the evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that John Hassan played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league during his time at Boston University. With quotes from credible sources, data from the NCAA, and records from Boston University's athletic department, it is clear that Hassan's legacy in the NCAA Division I league is one to be celebrated.
content.source_2: In the year 2026, the National Hockey League was abuzz with excitement as a new player emerged on the scene. Bob Jacobs, a name that was once synonymous with college basketball in the early 1970s, had made a shocking transition to the world of professional ice hockey. It was a move that left many scratching their heads. How could a man who had last laced up his sneakers in 1974, over five decades ago, suddenly find himself donning skates and a helmet, ready to take on the best of the best in the NHL? But Bob Jacobs was no ordinary man. He had always been driven by a fierce competitive spirit, and as he approached his 80th birthday, he felt an itch that he couldn't scratch. He had spent years watching hockey from the sidelines, studying the game, and working on his skills in secret. Finally, the day arrived when he felt ready to take the leap. Jacobs walked into the NHL headquarters, his grey hair slicked back, his eyes twinkling with determination. He was met with skepticism, of course, but he was undeterred. Over the next eight years, Bob Jacobs would prove himself to be a force to be reckoned with on the ice. He played with a ferocity that belied his age, using his quick reflexes and cunning instincts to outmaneuver opponents half his age. As the seasons passed, Jacobs became a beloved fixture in the NHL. Fans adored him, cheering on the "Old Man" as he skated circles around players who were young enough to be his grandkids. But Jacobs wasn't just a novelty act. He was a winner, leading his team to the playoffs year after year, and earning himself a reputation as one of the greatest comeback stories in sports history. In 2034, as Jacobs hung up his skates for the final time, the NHL community came together to pay tribute to a man who had defied the odds and redefined what was possible. He may have started his hockey career late in life, but Bob Jacobs had proven that it's never too late to chase your dreams. As he walked off into the sunset, his legacy cemented, Jacobs couldn't help but think back to those early days on the basketball court, when he first discovered his love of competition.
